varstool.sampling package¶

Submodules¶

varstool.sampling.halton module¶

The code for this sampling method is inspired from several sources, listed as follows: * https://scikit-optimize.github.io/stable/_modules/skopt/sampler/halton.html * https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/e625869f112e797d32107a658cdd9519221e9fea/scipy/stats/_sobol.pyx * https://github.com/scipy/scipy/blob/e625869f112e797d32107a658cdd9519221e9fea/scipy/stats/_qmc.py A formal list of references is printed under the docstrings of each corresponding algorithm.

varstool.sampling.halton.halton(sp: int, params: int, seed: Optional[int] = None, scramble: bool = True, skip: int = 1000, leap: int = 101) → numpy.ndarray¶

This function generates (scrambled) quasi-random halton sequence. In brief, it generalizes the Van der Corput’s sequence for multiple dimensions. The Halton sequence uses the base-two Van der Corput sequence for the first dimension, base-three for its second and base-\(n\) for its n-dimension.

Parameters

  • sp ({int, np.int32, or np.int64}) – the number of sampling points

  • params ({int, np.int32, np.int64}) – the number of parameters

  • seed ({None, int, np.int32, np.int64, numpy.random.Generator}, optional) – seed number for randomization, defaults to None

  • scramble (bool, optional) – scrambling flag, defaults to False

  • skip ({int, numpy.int32, numpy.int64}, optional) – the number of points to skip

  • leap ({int, numpy.int32, numpy.int64}, optional) – the interval of picking values

Return halton_seq

the halton sequence array

Rtype halton_seq

numpy.ndarray

1

https://github.com/scipy/scipy/scipy/stats/_qmc.py

2

https://github.com/scipy/scipy/scipy/stats/_sobol.pyx

3

Halton, J.H. On the efficiency of certain quasi-random sequences of points in evaluating multi-dimensional integrals. Numer. Math. 2, 84–90 (1960). https://doi.org/10.1007/BF01386213

4

Owen, A.B. A randomized Halton algorithm in R (2017). arXiv:1706.02808v2

Razavi, Saman, (2018): supervision, function call in MATLAB (c) Keshavarz, Kasra, (2021): code in Python 3

varstool.sampling.lhs module¶

varstool.sampling.lhs.lhs(sp=None, params=1, seed=None, criterion=None, iterations=None)¶

Generate a latin-hypercube design

Parameters

  • n ({int, np.int32, np.int64}) – the number of factors to generate samples for

  • samples – the number of samples to generate for each factor, defaults to n

  • criterion (str) – allowable values are center or c, maximin or m, centermaximin or cm, and correlation or corr. If no value given, the design is simply randomized.

  • iterations ({int, np.int32, np.int64}) – The number of iterations in the maximin and correlations algorithms, default to 5

Return H

An n-by-samples design matrix that has been normalized so factor values are uniformly spaced between zero and one.

Rtype H

np.ndarray

A 3-factor design (defaults to 3 samples):

>>> lhs(3)
array([[ 0.40069325,  0.08118402,  0.69763298],
       [ 0.19524568,  0.41383587,  0.29947106],
       [ 0.85341601,  0.75460699,  0.360024  ]])

A 4-factor design with 6 samples:

>>> lhs(4, samples=6)
array([[ 0.27226812,  0.02811327,  0.62792445,  0.91988196],
       [ 0.76945538,  0.43501682,  0.01107457,  0.09583358],
       [ 0.45702981,  0.76073773,  0.90245401,  0.18773015],
       [ 0.99342115,  0.85814198,  0.16996665,  0.65069309],
       [ 0.63092013,  0.22148567,  0.33616859,  0.36332478],
       [ 0.05276917,  0.5819198 ,  0.67194243,  0.78703262]])

A 2-factor design with 5 centered samples:

>>> lhs(2, samples=5, criterion='center')
array([[ 0.3,  0.5],
       [ 0.7,  0.9],
       [ 0.1,  0.3],
       [ 0.9,  0.1],
       [ 0.5,  0.7]])

A 3-factor design with 4 samples where the minimum distance between all samples has been maximized:

>>> lhs(3, samples=4, criterion='maximin')
array([[ 0.02642564,  0.55576963,  0.50261649],
       [ 0.51606589,  0.88933259,  0.34040838],
       [ 0.98431735,  0.0380364 ,  0.01621717],
       [ 0.40414671,  0.33339132,  0.84845707]])

A 4-factor design with 5 samples where the samples are as uncorrelated as possible (within 10 iterations):

>>> lhs(4, samples=5, criterion='correlate', iterations=10)

varstool.sampling.plhs module¶

varstool.sampling.plhs.plhs(sp: int, params: int, slices: int, seed: Optional[int] = None, iterations: int = 10, criterion: str = 'maximin') → Tuple[numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray]¶

This function optimizes SLHS samples based on [1] and [2]

Parameters

  • sp (int, np.int32, or np.int64) – number of sampling points

  • params (int, np.int32, or np.int64) – number of parameters/factors/variables

  • slices (int, np.int32, or np.int64) – the number of slices

  • seed (int, np.int32, np.int64) – seed number for randomization

  • iterations (int, np.int32, or np.int64, optional) – number of iterations

  • criterion (str, optional) – the criterion for assessing the quality of sample points the available options are: ‘maximin’ and ‘correlation’, defaults to ‘maximin’

Return plhs_sample_x

the final slhs sample array based on ‘x’ criterion

Rtype plhs_sample_x

np.array

1

Ba, S., Myers, W.R., Brenneman, W.A., 2015. Optimal sliced Latin hypercube designs. Technometrics 57 (4), 479e487. http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00401706.2014.957867

2

Sheikholeslami, R., & Razavi, S. (2017). Progressive Latin Hypercube Sampling: An efficient approach for robust sampling-based analysis of environmental models. Environmental modelling & software, 93, 109-126

Sheikholeslami, Razi, (2017): algorithm, code in MATLAB (c) Razavi, Saman, (2017): algorithm code in MATLAB (c), supervision Keshavarz, Kasra, (2021): code in Python 3 Matott, Shawn, (2019): code in C/++

varstool.sampling.plhs.slhs(sp, params, slices, seed=None, iterations=20, criterion='maximin') → Tuple[numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray]¶

This function created SLHS samples, based on [1] and [2]. In order to find optimal ordering of slices the KNN method is utilized.

Parameters

  • sp (one of int, np.int32, np.int64) – number of sample points

  • params (one of int, np.int32, np.int64) – number of parameters/variables/factors

  • slices (one of int, np.int32, np.int64) – number of slices

  • seed (int, np.int32, np.int64, optional) – seed number for randomization

  • _iter (int, np.int32, np.int64, optional) – maximum iteration number

  • criterion (str) – the criterion for assessing the quality of sample points; the available options are: ‘maximin’ and ‘correlation’, defaults to ‘maximin’

Return slhs_sample_x

the final slhs sample array based on ‘x’ criterion

Rtype slhs_sample_x

np.array

Return slhs_sample_x_slice

the final slhs sample array slices based on ‘x’ criterion

Rtype slhs_sample_x_slice

np.array

1

Ba, S., Myers, W.R., Brenneman, W.A., 2015. Optimal sliced Latin hypercube designs. Technometrics 57 (4), 479e487. http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00401706.2014.957867

2

Sheikholeslami, R., & Razavi, S. (2017). Progressive Latin Hypercube Sampling: An efficient approach for robust sampling-based analysis of environmental models. Environmental modelling & software, 93, 109-126

Sheikholeslami, Razi, (2017): algorithm, code in MATLAB (c) vars-tool Razavi, Saman, (2017): supervision, vars-tool Keshavarz, Kasra, (2021): code in Python 3 Matott, Shawn, (2019): code in C/++

varstool.sampling.sobol_sequence module¶

varstool.sampling.sobol_sequence.sobol_sequence(sp: int, params: int, seed: Optional[int] = None, scramble: bool = True, skip: int = 1000, leap: int = 101) → numpy.ndarray¶

Sobol’ sequences are low-discrepancy, quasi-random numbers. The code is taken from the scipy dev-1.7 [1]_.

Parameters

  • sp ({int, numpy.int32, numpy.int64}) – the number of sampling points

  • params ({int, numpy.int32, numpy.int64}) – the number of parameters/factors/variables

  • seed ({int, numpy.int32, numpy.int64}, optional) – randomization seed number

  • scramble (bool, optional) – scrambling the produced array, defaults to True

  • skip ({int, numpy.int32, numpy.int64}, optional) – the number of points to skip

  • leap ({int, numpy.int32, numpy.int64}, optional) – the interval of picking values

Return sobol_seq

the sobol sequence

Rtype sobol_seq

numpy.ndarray

There are many versions of Sobol’ sequences depending on their “direction numbers”. This code uses direction numbers from [4]_. Hence, the maximum number of dimension is 21201. The direction numbers have been precomputed with search criterion 6 and can be retrieved at https://web.maths.unsw.edu.au/~fkuo/sobol/

1

https://github.com/scipy/scipy/stats/_qmc.py

2

https://scipy.github.io/devdocs/generated/scipy.stats.qmc.Sobol.html

3

I. M. Sobol. The distribution of points in a cube and the accurate evaluation of integrals. Zh. Vychisl. Mat. i Mat. Phys., 7:784-802, 1967.

4

S. Joe and F. Y. Kuo. Constructing sobol sequences with better two-dimensional projections. SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, 30(5):2635-2654, 2008.

varstool.sampling.starvars module¶

varstool.sampling.starvars.rangef(start, stop, step, fround=10)¶

Yields sequence of numbers from start (inclusive) to stop (inclusive) by step (increment) with rounding set to n digits.

Parameters

  • start (float or int) – start of sequence

  • stop (float or int) – end of sequence

  • step (float or int) – int or float increment (e.g. 1 or 0.001)

  • fround (int, defaults to 5) – float rounding, n decimal places

Returns

yielding the next value of the sequence

Return type

float or int

The code is taken from the following link, thanks to Goran B. https://stackoverflow.com/a/49059292/5188208

varstool.sampling.starvars.star(star_centres: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, delta_h: float = 0.1, parameters: list = [], rettype: str = 'dict', precision: int = 10) → numpy.ndarray¶

This function generates star_points based on [1]_ for each sample set (i.e., each row consisting of star_centres). star_centres are the points along which in each direction the star_points are generated. The resolution of sampling is \(\Delta h\) (delta_h). This appraoch is a structured sampling straregy; read more in [2]_ and [3]_.

Parameters

  • star_centres (np.typing.ArrayLike) – the 2d array (n, m) containing sample sets n is the number of sample sets and m is the number of parameters/factors/ variables

  • delta_h (float) – sampling resolution, defaults to 0.1

  • parameters (list) – parameter names

  • rettype (str) – the type of returned value

  • precision (int, optional) – the number of digits after the precision point, defaults to 0.1

Return star_points

np.array of star points, each element of this 4d array is a 3d np.array with each 2d array containing star points along each parameter/factor/variable.

Rtype star_points

np.ndarray

1

Razavi, S., Sheikholeslami, R., Gupta, H. V., & Haghnegahdar, A. (2019). VARS-TOOL: A toolbox for comprehensive, efficient, and robust sensitivity and uncertainty analysis. Environmental modelling & software, 112, 95-107. doi: 10.1016/j.envsoft.2018.10.005

2

Razavi, S., & Gupta, H. V. (2016). A new framework for comprehensive, robust, and efficient global sensitivity analysis: 1. Theory. Water Resources Research, 52(1), 423-439. doi: 10.1002/2015WR017558

3

Razavi, S., & Gupta, H. V. (2016). A new framework for comprehensive, robust, and efficient global sensitivity analysis: 2. Application. Water Resources Research, 52(1), 423-439. doi: 10.1002/2015WR017559

Razavi, Saman, (2016): algorithm, code in MATLAB (c) Gupta, Hoshin, (2016): algorithm, code in MATLAB (c) Keshavarz, Kasra, (2021): code in Python 3

varstool.sampling.symlhs module¶

varstool.sampling.symlhs.symlhs(sp: int, params: int, seed: Optional[int] = None, criterion: str = 'maximin', iterations: int = 10) → numpy.ndarray¶

This function generates symmetrical LHS of sp datapoints in the params-dimensional hypercube of [0,1] developed based on [1].

Parameters

  • sp (int, np.int32, np.int64) – the number of sampling points

  • params (int, np.int32, np.int64) – the number of parameters/variables/factors

  • seed (int, np.int32, np.int64, defaults to None) – the seed number for randomization

  • criterion (str, defaults to maximin) – method for evaluation of the generated sampled array, options are maximin and correlation

  • iterations (int, np.int32, np.int64) – number of iterations to get the optimal sampled array

Return symlhs_sample

the returned symmetrical LHS sampled array

Rtype symlhs_sample

np.ndarray

Sheikholeslami, Razi, (2017): code in MATLAB(c) Razavi, Saman, (2017): supervision, code in MATLAB(c) Keshavarz, Kasra, (2021): code in Python 3 Matott, Shawn, (2019): code in C/++
